poem:
"An Elegy to the Architect"

In Essex, houses stand, testament to Bryan.
A builder of buildings, Creator of Comfort.
His churches, a communion of concrete and sky,
Schools, stoic sentries of knowledge.
Life he shaped in floorplans and façade,
Crafted living, bedrooms in the sky.
Bryan gone, his monuments remain,
An architect's lesson in the permanence of impermanence.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Bryan Thomas obituary My stepfather, Bryan Thomas, who has died aged 95, was an architect and designer who was responsible for the design of many houses in north-east Essex during his long career. Bryan’s practice also designed schools, churches, community centres, a Quaker meeting room and buildings at Essex University. Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
